Name: Bride-wealth
Description: Bride-price or bride-wealth, i.e., transfer of a substantial consideration in the form of livestock, goods, or money from the groom or his relatives to the kinsmen of the bride

Name: Bride-service
Description: Bride-service, i.e., a substantial material consideration in which the principal element consists of labor or other services rendered by the groom to the bride's kinsmen

Name: Token bride-wealth
Description: Token bride-price, i.e., a small or symbolic payment only

Name: Gift exchange
Description: Gift exchange, i.e., reciprocal exchange of gifts of substantial value between the relatives of the bride and groom, or a continuing exchange of goods and services in approximately equal amounts between the groom or his kinsmen and the bride's relatives

Name: Woman exchange
Description: Exchange, i.e., transfer of a sister or other female relative of the groom in exchange for the bride

Name: Insignificant
Description: Absence of any significant consideration, or bridal gifts only

Name: Dowry
Description: Dowry, i.e., transfer of a substantial amount of property from the bride's relatives to the bride, the groom, or the kinsmen of the latter

Name: Bride-wealth
Description: Bride-price or bride-wealth, i.e., transfer of a substantial consideration in the form of livestock, goods, or money from the groom or his relatives to the kinsmen of the bride

Name: Bride-service
Description: Bride-service, i.e., a substantial material consideration in which the principal element consists of labor or other services rendered by the groom to the bride's kinsmen

Name: Token bride-wealth
Description: Token bride-price, i.e., a small or symbolic payment only

Name: Gift exchange
Description: Gift exchange, i.e., reciprocal exchange of gifts of substantial value between the relatives of the bride and groom, or a continuing exchange of goods and services in approximately equal amounts between the groom or his kinsmen and the bride's relatives

Name: Woman exchange
Description: Exchange, i.e., transfer of a sister or other female relative of the groom in exchange for the bride

Name: Insignificant
Description: Absence of any significant consideration, or bridal gifts only

Name: Dowry
Description: Dowry, i.e., transfer of a substantial amount of property from the bride's relatives to the bride, the groom, or the kinsmen of the latter

Name: No alternate
Description: No alternate mode or supplementary practices, see "Mode of marriage (primary)"

Name: Nuclear, limited polygyny
Description: Independent nuclear families with occasional or limited polygyny

Name: Polygyny, atypical cowives pattern
Description: Independent polygynous families, unusual co-wives pattern (either polygyny is preferentially sororal, with cowives in separate quarters or it is typically non-sororal, with cowives in same quarters

Name: Polygyny, typical cowives pattern
Description: Independent polygynous families, usual co-wives pattern (either polygyny is preferentially sororal, with cowives in same quarters, OR typically non-sororal, with cowives in separate quarters)

Name: Minimal extended
Description: Minimal extended or "stem" families, i.e., those consisting of only two related families of procreation (disregarding polygamous unions), particularly of adjacent generations

Name: Small extended
Description: Small extended families, i.e., those normally embracing the families of procreation of only one individual in the senior generation but of at least two in the next generation. Such families usually dissolve on the death of the head

Name: Large extended
Description: Large extended families, i.e., corporate aggregations of smaller family units occupying a single dwelling or a number of adjacent dwellings and normally embracing the families of procreation of at least two siblings or cousins in each of at least two adjacent generations

Name: Limited polygyny
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny occasional or limited

Name: Polygyny, sororal cohabit
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny common and preferentially sororal, and co-wives not reported to occupy separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, sororal separate
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny common and preferentially sororal, and co-wives typically occupying separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, non-sororal cohabit
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny general and not reported to be preferentially sororal, and co-wives typically occupying separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, non-sororal separate
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny general and not reported to be preferentially sororal, and co-wives not reported to occupy separate quarters

Name: Avunculocal
Description: Avunculocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the maternal uncle or other male matrilineal kinsmen of the husband

Name: Ambilocal
Description: Ambilocal, i.e., residence established optionally with or near the parents of either the husband or the wife, depending upon circumstances or personal choice, where neither alternative exceeds the other in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one.

Name: Avuncu-uxorilocal
Description: Optionally uxorilocal or avunculocal. This may be the case in a uxorilocal society where many men marry a MoBrDa and thus, in fact, live avunculocally

Name: Matrilocal
Description: Matrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the female matrilineal kinsmen of the wife. Cf. U Uxorilocal

Name: Neolocal
Description: Neolocal, i.e., normal residence apart from the relatives of both spouses or at a place not determined by the kin ties of either

Name: Separate
Description: Nonestablishment of a common household, i.e., where both spouses remain in their natal households, sometimes called "duolocal" or "natolocal" residence

Name: Patrilocal
Description: Patrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the male patrilineal kinsmen of the husband. Cf. V Virilocal

Name: Uxorilocal
Description: Uxorilocal. Equivalent to "matrilocal" but confined to instances where the wife's matrikin are not aggregated in matrilocal and matrilineal kin groups

Name: Virilocal
Description: Virilocal. Equivalent to "patrilocal" but confined to instances where the husband's patrikin are not aggregated in patrilocal and patrilineal kin groups

Name: Ambi-uxo
Description: Ambilocal, with a marked preponderance of uxorilocal practice (i.e., uxorilocal option exceeds virilocal option in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one).

Name: Ambi-viri
Description: Ambilocal, with a marked preponderance of virilocal practice (i.e., virilocal option exceeds uxorilocal option in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one).

Name: Different
Description: Pattern of marital residence differs in the first years of marriage relative to later years.

Name: Same
Description: Pattern of marital residence in the first years of marriage not different from later years.

Name: Wife to husband
Description: Wife to husband's group (patrilocal, virilocal) or wife to husband's mother's brother's household (avunculocal)

Name: Ambi/neo-local
Description: Couple to either group or neolocal

Name: Separate
Description: Nonestablishment of a common household, i.e., where both spouses remain in their natal households, sometimes called "duolocal" or "natolocal" residence

Name: Avunculocal
Description: Avunculocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the maternal uncle or other male matrilineal kinsmen of the husband

Name: Ambilocal
Description: Ambilocal, i.e., residence established optionally with or near the parents of either the husband or the wife, depending upon circumstances or personal choice, where neither alternative exceeds the other in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one.

Name: Avuncu-uxorilocal
Description: Optionally uxorilocal or avunculocal. This may be the case in a uxorilocal society where many men marry a MoBrDa and thus, in fact, live avunculocally

Name: Matrilocal
Description: Matrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the female matrilineal kinsmen of the wife. Cf. U Uxorilocal

Name: Neolocal
Description: Neolocal, i.e., normal residence apart from the relatives of both spouses or at a place not determined by the kin ties of either

Name: Separate
Description: Nonestablishment of a common household, i.e., where both spouses remain in their natal households, sometimes called "duolocal" or "natolocal" residence

Name: Patrilocal
Description: Patrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the male patrilineal kinsmen of the husband. Cf. V Virilocal

Name: Uxorilocal
Description: Uxorilocal. Equivalent to "matrilocal" but confined to instances where the wife's matrikin are not aggregated in matrilocal and matrilineal kin groups

Name: Virilocal
Description: Virilocal. Equivalent to "patrilocal" but confined to instances where the husband's patrikin are not aggregated in patrilocal and patrilineal kin groups

Name: Ambi-uxo
Description: Ambilocal, with a marked preponderance of uxorilocal practice (i.e., uxorilocal option exceeds virilocal option in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one).

Name: Ambi-viri
Description: Ambilocal, with a marked preponderance of virilocal practice (i.e., virilocal option exceeds uxorilocal option in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one).

Name: Wife to husband
Description: Wife to husband's group (patrilocal, virilocal) or wife to husband's mother's brother's household (avunculocal)

Name: Ambi/neo-local
Description: Couple to either group or neolocal

Name: Avunculocal
Description: Avunculocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the maternal uncle or other male matrilineal kinsmen of the husband

Name: Ambilocal
Description: Ambilocal, i.e., residence established optionally with or near the parents of either the husband or the wife, depending upon circumstances or personal choice, where neither alternative exceeds the other in actual frequency by a ratio greater than two to one.

Name: Avuncu-uxorilocal
Description: Optionally uxorilocal or avunculocal. This may be the case in a uxorilocal society where many men marry a MoBrDa and thus, in fact, live avunculocally

Name: Matrilocal
Description: Matrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the female matrilineal kinsmen of the wife. Cf. U Uxorilocal

Name: Neolocal
Description: Neolocal, i.e., normal residence apart from the relatives of both spouses or at a place not determined by the kin ties of either

Name: Separate
Description: Nonestablishment of a common household, i.e., where both spouses remain in their natal households, sometimes called "duolocal" or "natolocal" residence

Name: Patrilocal
Description: Patrilocal, i.e., normal residence with or near the male patrilineal kinsmen of the husband. Cf. V Virilocal

Name: Uxorilocal
Description: Uxorilocal. Equivalent to "matrilocal" but confined to instances where the wife's matrikin are not aggregated in matrilocal and matrilineal kin groups

Name: Virilocal
Description: Virilocal. Equivalent to "patrilocal" but confined to instances where the husband's patrikin are not aggregated in patrilocal and patrilineal kin groups

Name: Demes
Description: Demes, i.e., communities revealing a marked tendency toward local endogamy but not segmented into clan-barrios

Name: Segmented, no exogamy
Description: Segmented communities, i.e., those divided into barrios, wards, or hamlets, each of which is essentially a localized kin group, a clan or ramage, in the absence of any indication of local exogamy. Large extended families (see "Domestic organization"), are treated as clan-barrios if they are integrated by a rule of ambilineal, matrilineal, or patrilineal descent.

Name: Agamous
Description: Agamous communities without localized clans or any marked tendency toward either local exogamy or local endogamy

Name: Exogamous
Description: Exogamous communities, i.e., those revealing a marked tendency toward local exogamy without having the specific structure of clans

Name: Segmented, exogamy
Description: Segmented communities where a marked tendency toward local exogamy is also specifically reported

Name: Clans
Description: Clan-communities, each consisting essentially of a single localized exogamous kin group or clan (see "Organization of clan communities" for more detail)

Name: Clans
Description: Clan communities not segmented into clan barrios

Name: Clans with barrios
Description: Clan communities segmented into clan barrios

Name: No exogamous clans
Description: Communities not organized as exogamous clan communities

Name: Exogamy only
Description: Absence of true patrilineal kin groups, but presence of patrilineal exogamy

Name: Lineages
Description: Lineages of modest size, i.e., patrilineal kin groups whose core membership is normally confined to a single community or a part thereof

Name: Sibs
Description: Sibs ("clans" in British usage), i.e., lineages whose core membership normally comprises residents of more than one community

Name: Phratries
Description: Phratries, i.e., maximal lineages when there are more than two in the society and when sibs are also present. Segmentary lineage systems in which segments of a lower order of magnitude are equivalent to sibs are also included in this category.

Name: Moieties
Description: Moieties, i.e., maximal lineages when there are only two such in the society

Name: Extended taboo
Description: Extension of incest taboos to known patrilineal kinsmen, provided such extension does not apply generally to bilateral kinsmen of equal remoteness

Name: Lineages
Description: Lineages of modest size, i.e., patrilineal kin groups whose core membership is normally confined to a single community or a part thereof

Name: Sibs
Description: Sibs ("clans" in British usage), i.e., lineages whose core membership normally comprises residents of more than one community

Name: Phratries
Description: Phratries, i.e., maximal lineages when there are more than two in the society and when sibs are also present. Segmentary lineage systems in which segments of a lower order of magnitude are equivalent to sibs are also included in this category.

Name: Moieties
Description: Moieties, i.e., maximal lineages when there are only two such in the society

Name: Exogamy only
Description: Absence of true matrilineal kin groups, but presence of matrilineal exogamy

Name: Lineages
Description: Lineages of modest size, i.e., matrilineal kin groups whose core membership is normally confined to a single community or a part thereof

Name: Sibs
Description: Sibs ("clans" in British usage), i.e., lineages whose core membership normally comprises residents of more than one community

Name: Phratries
Description: Phratries, i.e., maximal lineages when there are more than two in the society and when sibs are also present. Segmentary lineage systems in which segments of a lower order of magnitude are equivalent to sibs are also included in this category.

Name: Moieties
Description: Moieties, i.e., maximal lineages when there are only two such in the society

Name: Extended taboo
Description: Extension of incest taboos to known matrilineal kinsmen, provided extension does not apply generally to bilateral kinsmen of equal remoteness.

Name: Lineages
Description: Lineages of modest size, i.e., matrilineal kin groups whose core membership is normally confined to a single community or a part thereof

Name: Sibs
Description: Sibs ("clans" in British usage), i.e., lineages whose core membership normally comprises residents of more than one community

Name: Phratries
Description: Phratries, i.e., maximal lineages when there are more than two in the society and when sibs are also present. Segmentary lineage systems in which segments of a lower order of magnitude are equivalent to sibs are also included in this category.

Name: Moieties
Description: Moieties, i.e., maximal lineages when there are only two such in the society

Name: Bilateral inferred
Description: Bilateral descent as inferred from the absence of reported ambilineal, matrilineal, or patrilineal kin groups, kindreds being absent or unreported

Name: Bilateral kindreds
Description: Kindreds: bilateral descent with specifically reported kindreds, i.e., Ego-oriented bilateral kin groups or categories

Name: Ambilineal
Description: Ambilineal descent inferred from the presence of ambilocal extended families, true ramages being absent or unreported

Name: Ramages
Description: Ramages, i.e., ancestor-oriented ambilineal kin groups, if they are agamous, endogamous, or not specifically stated to be exogamous

Name: Quasi-lineages
Description: Bilateral descent with reported or probable quasi-lineages, i.e., cognatic groups approximating the structure of lineages but based on filiation rather than on unilineal or ambilineal descent

Name: No cognatic kin
Description: Absence of cognatic kin groups as inferred from the presence of unilineal descent

Name: Kindreds
Description: Kindreds: bilateral descent with specifically reported kindreds, i.e., Ego-oriented bilateral kin groups or categories

Name: Ramages
Description: Ramages, i.e., ancestor-oriented ambilineal kin groups, if they are agamous, endogamous, or not specifically stated to be exogamous

Name: Cross-cousin
Description: Duolateral cross-cousin marriage permitted, i.e., marriage allowed with either MoBrDa or FaSiDa but forbidden with a parallel cousin

Name: Paternal only
Description: Duolateral marriage permitted with paternal cousins only (FaBrDa or FaSiDa)

Name: Maternal only
Description: Duolateral marriage permitted with maternal cousins only (MoBrDa or MoSiDa)

Name: FaBrDa/MoBrDa only
Description: Duolateral marriage permitted with an uncle's daughter only (FaBrDa or MoBrDa)

Name: FaSiDa/MoSiDa only
Description: Duolateral marriage permitted with an aunt's daughter only (FaSiDa or MoSiDa)

Name: Matrilateral cross only
Description: Unilateral: only matrilateral cross-cousin marriage permitted, i.e., with a MoBrDa

Name: No first/second cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage, i.e., unions forbidden with any first or second cousin

Name: No first cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage, evidence available only for first cousins

Name: Patrilateral cross only
Description: Unilateral: only patrilateral cross-cousin marriage permitted i.e., with a FaSiDa

Name: Any first cousins
Description: Quadrilateral marriage, i.e., marriage allowed with any first cousin

Name: Some second only
Description: Nonlateral marriage in which all first cousins and some but not all second cousins are forbidden as spouses

Name: Only second cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage in which unions are forbidden with any first cousin but are permitted with any second cousin (or at least any who is not a lineage mate)

Name: Trilateral
Description: Trilateral marriage, i.e., marriage allowed with any first cousin except an orthocousin or lineage mate

Name: Quadrilateral
Description: Quadrilateral marriage, i.e., marriage allowed with any first cousin

Name: Trilateral
Description: Trilateral marriage, i.e., marriage allowed with any first cousin except an orthocousin or lineage mate

Name: Duolateral
Description: Two of four first cousins marriageable

Name: Unilateral
Description: One of four first cousins marriageable

Name: Only second cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage in which unions are forbidden with any first cousin but are permitted with any second cousin (or at least any who is not a lineage mate)

Name: Some second only
Description: Nonlateral marriage in which all first cousins and some but not all second cousins are forbidden as spouses

Name: No first cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage when evidence is available only for first cousins

Name: No first/second cousins
Description: Nonlateral marriage, i.e., unions forbidden with any first or second cousin

Name: Cross-cousin: either
Description: Duolateral, symmetrical preference for MoBrDa or FaSiDa

Name: Maternal: MoBrDa
Description: Duolateral, with maternal cousins only and MoBrDa preferred

Name: Uni: MoBrDa
Description: Unilateral: matrilateral cross-cousin marriage to MoBrDa preferred rather than merely permitted

Name: Uni: FaSiDa
Description: Unilateral: patrilateral cross-cousin marriage to FaSiDa preferred rather than merely permitted

Name: All: FaBrDa
Description: Quadrilateral, where FaBrDa is the preferred mate

Name: Some second only
Description: Nonlateral, with preference for particular second cross-cousins only, notably MoMoBrDaDa or FaMoBrSoDa, often reported of societies with subsection systems

Name: Second cousins preferred
Description: Nonlateral, with second-cousin marriage preferred rather than merely permitted

Name: Tri: bilateral
Description: Trilateral marriage, with preference for a bilateral cross-cousin (MoBrDa = FaSiDa).

Name: Tri: matrilateral
Description: Trilateral marriage, with preference for a matrilateral cross-cousin (MoBrDa)

Name: Tri: patrilateral
Description: Trilateral marriage, with preference for a patrilateral cross-cousin (FaSiDa)

Name: Cross-cousin
Description: A symmetrical cross-cousin is preferred spouse

Name: Crow
Description: Crow, i.e., FaSiCh equated with Fa or FaSi and/or MoBrCh with Ch or BrCh(ws)

Name: Descriptive
Description: Descriptive or derivative, rather than elementary, terms employed for all cousins

Name: Eskimo
Description: Eskimo, i.e., FaBrCh, FaSiCh, MoBrCh, and MoSiCh equated with each other but differentiated from siblings

Name: Hawaiian
Description: Hawaiian, i.e., all cousins equated with siblings or called by terms clearly derivative from those for siblings

Name: Iroquois
Description: Iroquois, i.e., FaSiCh equated with MoBrCh but differentiated from both siblings and parallel cousins

Name: Omaha
Description: Omaha, i.e., MoBrCh equated with MoBr or Mo and/or FaSiCh with SiCh(ms) or Ch

Name: Sudanese
Description: Sudanese, i.e., FaSiCh and MoBrCh distinguished alike from siblings, parallel cousins, and each other but without conforming to either the Crow, the descriptive, or the Omaha patterns

Name: Mixed
Description: Mixed or variant patterns not adequately represented by any of the foregoing symbols. The details are given under "Classification by Clusters."

Name: Casual
Description: Casual agriculture, i.e., the slight or sporadic cultivation of food or other plants incidental to a primary dependence upon other subsistence practices

Name: Extensive/shifting
Description: Extensive or shifting cultivation, as where new fields are cleared annually, cultivated for a year or two, and then allowed to revert to forest or brush for a long fallow period

Name: Horticulture
Description: Horticulture, i.e., semi-intensive agriculture limited mainly to vegetable gardens or groves of fruit trees rather than the cultivation of field crops

Name: Intensive
Description: Intensive agriculture on permanent fields, utilizing fertilization by compost or animal manure, crop rotation, or other techniques so that fallowing is either unnecessary or is confined to relatively short periods

Name: Intensive irrigated
Description: Intensive cultivation where it is largely dependent upon irrigation

Name: Non-food
Description: Non-food crops only, e.g., cotton or tobacco

Name: Vegetables
Description: Vegetables, e.g., cucurbits, greens, or legumes, when more important than other crops

Name: Tree-fruits
Description: Tree fruits, e.g., bananas, breadfruit, coconuts, or dates, when more important than cereal grains and root crops. Sago, unless specifically reported to be cultivated, is treated as a gathered product rather than a cultivated one

Name: Roots/tubers
Description: Roots or tubers, e.g., manioc, potatoes, taro, or yams, when more important than cereal grains and at least as important as tree crops or vegetables

Name: Cereals
Description: Cereal grains, e.g., maize, millet, rice, or wheat, when at least as important as any other type of crop

Name: Seminomadic
Description: Seminomadic communities whose members wander in bands for at least half of the year but occupy a fixed settlement at some season or seasons, e.g., recurrently occupied winter quarters

Name: Semisedentary
Description: Semisedentary communities whose members shift from one to another fixed settlement at different seasons or who occupy more or less permanently a single settlement from which a substantial proportion of the population departs seasonally to occupy shifting camps, e.g., during transhumance

Name: Impermanent
Description: Compact but impermanent settlements, i.e., villages whose location is shifted every few years

Name: Hamlets
Description: Separated hamlets where several such form a more or less permanent single community

Name: Villages/towns
Description: Compact and relatively permanent settlements, i.e., nucleated villages or towns

Name: Complex permanent
Description: Complex settlements consisting of a nucleated village or town with outlying homesteads or satellite hamlets. Urban aggregations of population are not separately indicated since EA031 deals with community size

Name: 1000+ no towns
Description: More than 1,000 persons in the absence of indigenous urban aggregations
One or more indigenous towns of more than 5,000 inhabitants but none of more than 50,000
One or more indigenous cities with more than 50,000 inhabitants

Name: Independent families
Description: Independent families (may be nuclear or polygynous)

Name: Acephalous
Description: No political authority beyond community (e.g., autonomous bands and villages)

Name: Absent
Description: A high god absent or not reported in substantial descriptions of religious beliefs

Name: Otiose
Description: A high god present but otiose or not concerned with human affairs

Name: Active, but not supporting morality
Description: A high god present and active in human affairs but not offering positive support to human morality

Name: Active, supporting morality
Description: A high god present, active, and specifically supportive of human morality

Name: No games
Description: No games of any of the three types

Name: Physical skill only
Description: Games of physical skill only, whether or not they may also involve incidental elements of chance or strategy, e.g., foot racing, wrestling, the hoop-and-pole game

Name: Chance only
Description: Games of chance only, with no significant element of either physical skill or strategy involved, e.g., dice games

Name: Physical skill and chance
Description: Games of physical skill and of chance both present

Name: Strategy only
Description: Games of strategy only, involving no significant element of physical skill, e.g., chess, go, poker. Whether or not an element of chance is also involved is considered irrelevant

Name: Strategy and physical skill
Description: Games of physical skill and of strategy present, but not games of chance

Name: Strategy and chance
Description: Games of chance and of strategy present, but not games of physical skill

Name: All types
Description: Games of all three types present

Name: No taboo
Description: No taboo, especially where the husband is expected to have intercourse with his wife as soon as possible after childbirth for the alleged benefit of the child

Name: Up to one month
Description: Short post-partum taboo, lasting not more than one month

Name: One to six months
Description: Duration of from more than a month to six months

Name: Six months to a year
Description: Duration of from more than six months to one year

Name: A year to two years
Description: Duration of from more than one year to two years

Name: More than two years
Description: Duration of more than two years

Name: Shortly after birth
Description: Performed shortly after birth, i.e., within the first two months

Name: Infancy
Description: Performed during infancy, i.e., from two months to two years of age

Name: Early childhood
Description: Performed during early childhood, i.e., from two to five years of age

Name: Late childhood
Description: Performed during late childhood, i.e., from six to ten years of age

Name: Adolescence
Description: Performed during adolescence, i.e., from eleven to fifteen years of age

Name: Early adulthood
Description: Performed during early adulthood, i.e., from sixteen to 25 years of age

Name: Maturity
Description: Performed during maturity, i.e., from 25 to 50 years of age

Name: Old age
Description: Performed in old age, i.e., after 50 years of age

Name: Customary, age unclear
Description: Circumcision customary, but the normal age is unspecified or unclear

Name: No segregation
Description: Absence of segregation, adolescent boys residing and sleeping in the same dwelling as their mothers and sisters

Name: Partial
Description: Partial segregation, adolescent boys residing or eating with their natal families but sleeping apart from them, e.g., in a special hut or in a cattle shed

Name: Complete: outside nuclear family
Description: Complete segregation, in which adolescent boys go to live as individuals with relatives outside the nuclear family, e.g., with grandparents or with a maternal or paternal uncle

Name: Complete: outside kin
Description: Complete segregation, in which adolescent boys go to live as individuals with non-relatives, e.g., as retainers to a chief or as apprentices to specialists

Name: Complete: own peers
Description: Complete segregation, in which boys reside with a group of their own peers, e.g., in bachelor dormitories, military regiments, or age-villages

Name: Not aboriginal but present
Description: Plow cultivation not aboriginal but well established at the period of observation

Name: Present
Description: Animals employed in plow cultivation prior to the contact period

Name: Absence or near absence
Description: Absence or near absence of domestic animals other than bees, eats, dogs, fowl, guinea pigs, or the like

Name: Pigs
Description: Pigs the only domestic animals of consequence

Name: Sheep/goats
Description: Sheep and/or goats when larger domestic animals are absent or much less important

Name: Camelids
Description: Camels or other animals of related genera, e.g., alpacas, llamas

Name: Bovine
Description: Bovine animals, e.g., cattle, mithun, water buffaloes, yaks

Name: Absence or near absence
Description: Absence or near absence of milking

Name: More than sporadically
Description: Domestic animals milked more often than sporadically

Name: Two or more sources
Description: Two or more sources contribute equally

Name: Ambilineal
Description: Ambilineal (EA017 = 1, EA019 = 1, EA021 = 3 or EA021 = 4 or EA021 = 5)

Name: Mixed
Description: Mixed (EA017  and/or EA019 > 1,and EA021 not equal to 9)

Name: Males alone
Description: Males alone perform the activity, female participation being negligible

Name: Both, males more
Description: Both sexes participate, but males do appreciably more than females

Name: Differentiated but equal
Description: Differentiation of specific tasks by sex but approximately equal participation by both sexes in the total activity

Name: Equal participation
Description: Equal participation by both sexes without marked or reported differentiation in specific tasks

Name: Both, females more
Description: Both sexes participate, but females do appreciably more than males

Name: Females alone
Description: Females alone perform the activity, male participation being negligible

Name: Sex irrelevant
Description: Sex participation irrelevant, especially where production is industrialized

Name: Activity present, sex diff. unspecified
Description: The activity is present, but sex participation is unspecified in the sources consulted

Name: Activity is absent
Description: The activity is absent or unimportant in the particular society

Name: Males alone
Description: Males alone perform the activity, female participation being negligible

Name: Both, males more
Description: Both sexes participate, but males do appreciably more than females

Name: Differentiated but equal
Description: Differentiation of specific tasks by sex but approximately equal participation by both sexes in the total activity

Name: Equal participation
Description: Equal participation by both sexes without marked or reported differentiation in specific tasks

Name: Both, females more
Description: Both sexes participate, but females do appreciably more than males

Name: Females alone
Description: Females alone perform the activity, male participation being negligible

Name: Sex irrelevant
Description: Sex participation irrelevant, especially where production is industrialized

Name: Activity present, sex diff. unspecified
Description: The activity is present, but sex participation is unspecified in the sources consulted

Name: Activity is absent
Description: The activity is absent or unimportant in the particular society

Name: Males alone
Description: Males alone perform the activity, female participation being negligible

Name: Both, males more
Description: Both sexes participate, but males do appreciably more than females

Name: Differentiated but equal
Description: Differentiation of specific tasks by sex but approximately equal participation by both sexes in the total activity

Name: Equal participation
Description: Equal participation by both sexes without marked or reported differentiation in specific tasks

Name: Both, females more
Description: Both sexes participate, but females do appreciably more than males

Name: Females alone

Name: Senior age

Name: Industrial

Name: Absence of distinctions
Description: Absence of significant class distinctions among freemen (slavery is treated in EA070), ignoring variations in individual repute achieved through skill, valor, piety, or wisdom

Name: Wealth distinctions
Description: Wealth distinctions, based on the possession or distribution of property, present and socially important but not crystallized into distinct and hereditary social classes

Name: Elite stratification
Description: Elite stratification, in which an elite class derives its superior status from, and perpetuates it through, control over scarce resources, particularly land, and is thereby differentiated from a property-less proletariat or serf class

Name: Dual stratification
Description: Dual stratification into a hereditary aristocracy and a lower class of ordinary commoners or freemen, where traditionally ascribed noble status is at least as decisive as control over scarce resources

Name: Complex stratification
Description: Complex stratification into social classes correlated in large measure with extensive differentiation of occupational statuses

Name: Absence of distinctions
Description: Absence of significant class distinctions among freemen (slavery is treated in EA070), ignoring variations in individual repute achieved through skill, valor, piety, or wisdom

Name: Wealth distinctions
Description: Wealth distinctions, based on the possession or distribution of property, present and socially important but not crystallized into distinct and hereditary social classes

Name: Elite stratification
Description: Elite stratification, in which an elite class derives its superior status from, and perpetuates it through, control over scarce resources, particularly land, and is thereby differentiated from a property-less proletariat or serf class

Name: Dual stratification
Description: Dual stratification into a hereditary aristocracy and a lower class of ordinary commoners or freemen, where traditionally ascribed noble status is at least as decisive as control over scarce resources

Name: Complex stratification
Description: Complex stratification into social classes correlated in large measure with extensive differentiation of occupational statuses

Name: Despised occupation groups
Description: One or more despised occupational groups, e.g., smiths or leather workers, distinguished from the general population, regarded as outcastes by the latter, and characterized by strict endogamy

Name: Ethnic stratification
Description: Ethnic stratification, in which a superordinate caste withholds privileges from and refuses to intermarry with a subordinate caste (or castes) which it stigmatizes as ethnically alien, e.g., as descended from a conquered and culturally inferior indigenous population, from former slaves, or from foreign immigrants of different race and/or culture

Name: Complex caste stratification
Description: Complex caste stratification in which occupational differentiation emphasizes hereditary ascription and endogamy to the near exclusion of achievable class statuses

Name: Despised occupation groups
Description: One or more despised occupational groups, e.g., smiths or leather workers, distinguished from the general population, regarded as outcastes by the latter, and characterized by strict endogamy

Name: Ethnic stratification
Description: Ethnic stratification, in which a superordinate caste withholds privileges from and refuses to intermarry with a subordinate caste (or castes) which it stigmatizes as ethnically alien, e.g., as descended from a conquered and culturally inferior indigenous population, from former slaves, or from foreign immigrants of different race and/or culture

Name: Complex caste stratification
Description: Complex caste stratification in which occupational differentiation emphasizes hereditary ascription and endogamy to the near exclusion of achievable class statuses

Name: Absence of slavery
Description: Absence or near absence of slavery

Name: Slavery, nonhereditary
Description: Incipient or nonhereditary slavery, i.e., where slave status is temporary and not transmitted to the children of slaves

Name: Slavery, no info on heritability
Description: Slavery reported but not identified as hereditary or nonhereditary

Name: Slavery, hereditary
Description: Hereditary slavery present and of at least modest social significance

Name: Past slavery
Description: Slavery present in past, but not currently in existence

Name: Past and present slavery
Description: Slavery present currently and in past

Name: Nonhered: appointed by auth.
Description: Nonhereditary succession through appointment by some higher authority

Name: Nonhered: seniority
Description: Nonhereditary succession on the basis primarily of seniority or age

Name: Nonhered: influence
Description: Nonhereditary succession through influence, e.g., of wealth or social status

Name: Nonhered: election
Description: Nonhereditary succession through election or some other mode of formal consensus

Name: Absence of office
Description: Absence of any office resembling that of a local headman

Name: Patrilineal heir
Description: Hereditary succession by a patrilineal heir who takes precedence over a son

Name: Sister's son
Description: Hereditary succession by a sister's son

Name: Matrilineal heir
Description: Hereditary succession by a matrilineal heir who takes precedence over a sister's son, e.g., a younger brother

Name: Absence of office
Description: Absence of any office resembling that of a local headman

Name: No inher. of real property
Description: Absence of individual property rights in land or of any rule of inheritance governing the transmission of such rights

Name: Matrilineal by sister's sons
Description: Matrilineal inheritance by a sister's son or sons

Name: Matrilineal by heirs
Description: Inheritance by matrilineal heirs who take precedence over sisters' sons

Name: Children, less for daughters
Description: Inheritance by children, but with daughters receiving less than sons

Name: Children
Description: Inheritance by children of either sex or both

Name: Patrilineal by heirs
Description: Inheritance by patrilineal heirs who take precedence over sons

Name: Patrilineal by sons
Description: Patrilineal inheritance by a son or sons

Name: Equally distributed
Description: Equal or relatively equal distribution among all members of the category

Name: Best qualified
Description: Exclusive or predominant inheritance by the member of the category adjudged best qualified, either by the deceased or by his surviving relatives

Name: Ultimogeniture
Description: Ultimogeniture, i.e., predominant inheritance by the junior member of the category

Name: Primogeniture
Description: Primogeniture, i.e., predominant inheritance by the senior member of the category

Name: No inher. of real property
Description: Absence of inheritance of real property

Name: No inher. of mov. property
Description: Absence of individual rights to movable property or of any rule of inheritance governing the transmission of such rights. This includes the destruction, burial, or giving away of movable property

Name: Matrilineal by sister's sons
Description: Matrilineal inheritance by a sister's son or sons

Name: Matrilineal by heirs
Description: Inheritance by matrilineal heirs who take precedence over sisters' sons

Name: Children, less for daughters
Description: Inheritance by children, but with daughters receiving less than sons

Name: Children
Description: Inheritance by children of either sex or both

Name: Patrilineal by heirs
Description: Inheritance by patrilineal heirs who take precedence over sons

Name: Patrilineal by sons
Description: Patrilineal inheritance by a son or sons

Name: Equally distributed
Description: Equal or relatively equal distribution among all members of the category

Name: Best qualified
Description: Exclusive or predominant inheritance by the member of the category adjudged best qualified, either by the deceased or by his surviving relatives

Name: Ultimogeniture
Description: Ultimogeniture, i.e., predominant inheritance by the junior member of the category

Name: Primogeniture
Description: Primogeniture, i.e., predominant inheritance by the senior member of the category

Name: No inher. of mov. property
Description: Absence of inheritance of movable property; includes the destruction, burial, or giving away of movable property

Name: Precluded by early marriage
Description: Premarital sex relations precluded by a very early age of marriage for females

Name: Prohibited, strongly sanctioned
Description: Insistence on virginity; premarital sex relations prohibited, strongly sanctioned, and in fact rare

Name: Prohibited but weakly sanctioned
Description: Premarital sex relations prohibited but weakly sanctioned and not infrequent in fact

Name: Permitted, sanction if pregnancy
Description: Premarital sex relations allowed and not sanctioned unless pregnancy results

Name: Trial marriage
Description: Trial marriage; monogamous premarital sex relations permitted with the expectation of marriage if pregnancy results, promiscuous relations being prohibited and sanctioned

Name: Permitted, no sanctions
Description: Premarital sex relations freely permitted and subject to no sanctions

Name: Elliptical
Description: Elliptical or elongated with rounded ends

Name: Quadrangular around interior
Description: Quadrangular around (or partially around) an interior court

Name: Subterranean
Description: Subterranean or semi-subterranean, ignoring cellars beneath the living quarters

Name: Floor level with ground
Description: Floor formed by or level with the ground itself

Name: Elevated slightly
Description: Elevated slightly above the ground on a raised platform of earth, stone, or wood

Name: Raised substantially
Description: Raised substantially above the ground on piles, posts, or piers

Name: Stone, stucco or brick
Description: Stone, stucco, concrete, or fired brick

Name: Plaster, clay or similar
Description: Plaster, mud and dung, or wattle and daub

Name: Wood, incl. bamboo
Description: Wood, including logs, planks, poles, bamboo, or shingles

Name: Open walls
Description: Open walls, including cases where they can be temporarily closed by screens

Name: Walls not diff. from roof
Description: Walls indistinguishable from roof or merging into the latter (see "Roofing materials" for details)

Name: Four slopes
Description: Hipped or pyramidal, i.e., with four slopes

Name: Plaster, clay or similar
Description: Plaster, clay, mud and dung, or wattle and daub

Name: Wood, incl. bamboo
Description: Wood, including logs, planks, poles, bamboo, or shingles

Name: Grass, leaves or thatch
Description: Grass, leaves, brush, or other thatch

Description: Elliptical or elongated with rounded ends

Description: Hipped or pyramidal, i.e., with four slopes
